images.copyright: Least chipmunk, Kootenai National Forest, Montana, United States (© Donald M. Jones/Minden Pictures)
images.title: The fast and the furriest
images.caption: Least chipmunk, Kootenai National Forest, Montana, United States
images.desc: In the world of woodland critters, the least chipmunk might seem like the 'undersquirrel'—but don't count it out. With survival smarts and turbo-charged feet, this tiny rodent proves that being 'least' is no reason to squirrel away your potential. Weighing less than a deck of cards and measuring under 30 centimetres from nose to tail, this species is North America's smallest chipmunk.

og.title: Least chipmunk, Kootenai National Forest, Montana, United States
og.desc: In the world of woodland critters, the least chipmunk might seem like the 'undersquirrel'—but don't count it out. With survival smarts and…

images.title: Carved stones of courage
images.caption: Chittorgarh Fort, Rajasthan
images.desc: High on a hill of 180 metres in Rajasthan, Chittorgarh Fort spans approximately 3 kilometres. It stands as a proud witness to the valour of the Rajputs. Their name comes from the Sanskrit 'rajaputra,' meaning 'son of a king,' and they are celebrated for their noble lineage and martial traditions across northern India. The fort's stone walls have witnessed centuries of courage, pride and romance, remembered in the songs of Rajasthan's bards. Local lore credits Bhim of the Pandavas, the five warrior princes of the Mahabharata, with laying its first foundations.

og.title: Chittorgarh Fort, Rajasthan

images.copyright: Devils Tower National Monument, Wyoming, United States (© Laura Hedien/Getty Images)
images.title: The lonely giant
images.caption: Devils Tower National Monument, Wyoming, United States
images.desc: Somewhere in the wide prairies of northeastern Wyoming in the United States, stands Devils Tower, a stone formation that rises from the open plains. As you approach Devils Tower, every curve in the road unveils a new view—whether you're arriving from the highway, winding toward the visitor centre or following the Tower Trail on foot. The site's significance stretches far deeper than its dramatic geology. For centuries, numerous tribes from the Great Plains and Black Hills, including the Arapaho, Crow and Cheyenne, have been linked to this place. Each tribe preserves oral traditions about the Tower's creation. Though themes overlap, each community preserves its own unique version.

og.title: Devils Tower National Monument, Wyoming, United States

images.copyright: Keel-billed toucan in Costa Rica (© Juan Carlos Vindas/Getty Images)
images.title: Beak-side story
images.caption: Keel-billed toucan, Costa Rica
images.desc: Spot a flash of yellow on its chest and a bill that looks painted by an artist—that's the keel-billed toucan. A member of the Ramphastidae family, which includes toucan barbets, it is one of more than 40 toucan species. Found from southern Mexico to northern Colombia, it spends much of its day plucking fruit with a rainbow-coloured bill about one-third of its total length. It also eats insects, eggs and small reptiles when available. The bill not only helps it eat but also keeps the toucan cool by radiating excess heat—thanks to the blood vessels running through it. This social bird often moves in small groups, chattering and gliding between treetops. With each wing measuring around 17–20 centimetres, the keel-billed toucan moults, or sheds its feathers, just once a year.

og.title: Keel-billed toucan, Costa Rica

images.copyright: Aspen trees during autumn Fishlake National Forest, Utah, United States (© Danita Delimont/Getty Images)
images.title: Midway to winter
images.caption: Autumn equinox
images.desc: Autumn isn't just marked by the calendar. Each September, Earth's subtle tilt brings the autumn equinox—one of two times a year when day and night are nearly equal in length. It marks the beginning of autumn in the Northern Hemisphere. From solar alignments to changing leaves, nature offers its own quiet signals that the season has shifted. While for most of us it may seem like just another day, ancient cultures paid close attention to this change. Sites like Chichén Itzá in Mexico and England's Stonehenge were designed to align with the rising or setting sun during equinox days.

og.title: Autumn equinox
og.desc: Autumn isn't just marked by the calendar. Each September, Earth's subtle tilt brings the autumn equinox—one of two times a year when day and…

images.copyright: Sea otters, Prince William Sound, Alaska, United States (© Gerald Corsi/Getty Images)
images.title: Otterly cool
images.caption: Sea otters, Prince William Sound, Alaska, United States
images.desc: Think sea otters are just about whiskers and floating naps? There's much more behind those button eyes. In Prince William Sound, in Alaska, United States, they drift on ice or crack shellfish on their bellies with a favourite rock, as seen in today's image. Less obvious is how their taste for sea urchins helps protect kelp forests. Otters also depend on clean, cold water—their fur traps air for warmth rather than repelling water, making them highly vulnerable to oil spills.

images.copyright: Swing carousel at Oktoberfest, Munich, Bavaria, Germany (© LOOK-foto/Alamy)
images.title: A tale of brews and views
images.caption: Oktoberfest begins!
images.desc: Every autumn, Theresienwiese, a square in Munich, Germany, transforms into one of the world's largest festivals—Oktoberfest. First held in 1810 to celebrate a royal wedding, it has grown into a 16- to 18-day tradition attracting more than six million people from around the globe. The scale is staggering: the festival grounds span around 4,20,000 square metres and host 14 main tents, each seating thousands. Each year, visitors consume around seven million litres of beer, along with mountains of pretzels, sausages and gingerbread hearts. All beer served at Oktoberfest comes from Munich breweries and meets the strict standards of the Reinheitsgebot, the German Beer Purity Law.

images.copyright: Thousand Islands region, St. Lawrence River, USA-Canada border (© benedek/Getty Images)
images.title: A thousand reasons to visit
images.caption: Thousand Islands region, St. Lawrence River, USA-Canada border
images.desc: When you hear 'Thousand Islands,' you might think of a jar of salad dressing, but behind that creamy condiment is one of North America's most enchanting regions. The Thousand Islands is an archipelago in the St. Lawrence River, spanning the state of New York in the United States and the province of Ontario in Canada. It is made up of more than 1,800 islands. Some of these islands have fairytale castles; others are barely big enough for a hammock. There's also Just Room Enough Island, which lives up to its name with a single house and a lone tree.
